title: version 1.8.27 can not use copied blockchain
body:
i moved .ethereum from one user to another on debian and it will not start , it gets stuck without outputting the error to stdin

```
root@debian:~/geth-linux-amd64-1.8.27-4bcc0a37# ./geth --verbosity=5 import blockchain_db  console
WARN [05-03|19:43:46.810] Sanitizing cache to Go's GC limits       provided=1024 updated=667
DEBUG[05-03|19:43:46.810] Sanitizing Go's GC trigger               percent=100
INFO [05-03|19:43:46.813] Maximum peer count                       ETH=25 LES=0 total=25
DEBUG[05-03|19:43:46.813] FS scan times                            list=76.538µs set=8.965µs diff=4.963µs
TRACE[05-03|19:43:46.813] Handled keystore changes                 time=124.654µs
TRACE[05-03|19:43:46.814] Started watching keystore folder         path=/root/.ethereum/keystore
INFO [05-03|19:43:46.815] Allocated cache and file handles         database=/root/.ethereum/geth/chaindata cache=333 handles=524288

```

Regardng `import`:
```
[user@work go-ethereum]$ build/bin/geth help import
import [command options] [arguments...]

The import command imports blocks from an RLP-encoded form. The form can be one file
with several RLP-encoded blocks, or several files can be used.

If only one file is used, import error will result in failure. If several files are used,
processing will proceed even if an individual RLP-file import failure occurs.

ETHEREUM OPTIONS:
  --datadir "/home/user/.ethereum"  Data directory for the databases and keystore
  --syncmode "fast"                 Blockchain sync mode ("fast", "full", or "light")
  --gcmode value                    Blockchain garbage collection mode ("full", "archive") (default: "full")

...
```
So basically, `import` is 

* When you have blocks, in `rlp` form, on disk (probably from a `geth export`, 
* and want to do a fullsync on those, importing them block by block. 

If you just want to copy the actual data, and move to another machine or folder, all you need to do is, 

* Copy the data to the new place, e..g `cp ~/.ethereum/geth/chaindata /foo/bazonk/geth/chaindata`
* Start geth with the new datadir

```
> mkdir -p /tmp/bazonk/geth
> cp -r ~/.ethereum/geth/* /tmp/bazonk/geth/
# If you copy the whole of .ethereum, you get the keystore aswell, which I omit here
> build/bin/geth --datadir /tmp/bazonk/
```
